TEXT.English: Oral tradition, oral culture and oral lore are messages or testimony transmitted orally from one generation to another. The messages or testimony are verbally transmitted in speech or song and may take the form, for example, of folktales, sayings, ballads, songs, or chants. In this way, it is possible for a society to transmit oral history, oral literature, oral law and other knowledges across generations without a writing system.
TEXT.French: Oral tradition, oral culture and oral lore are messages or testimony transmitted orally from one generation to another. In this way, it is possible for a society to transmit oral history, oral literature, oral law and other knowledges across generations without a writing system.

TEXT.English: Educated people benefit your economy by massivly increasesing your commerce (and thus can increase your research, gold, culture and espionage). Schools are essential for large cities with high commerce yields.
TEXT.French: Educated people benefit your economy by massivly increasesing your commerce (and thus can increase your research, gold, culture and espionage). Schools are essential for large cities with high commerce yields.

TEXT.English: The gymnasium in ancient Greece functioned as a training facility for competitors in public games. It was also a place for socializing and engaging in intellectual pursuits. The name comes from the Greek term gymnos meaning naked. Athletes competed in the nude, a practice said to encourage aesthetic appreciation of the male body and a tribute to the Gods.
TEXT.French: The gymnasium in ancient Greece functioned as a training facility for competitors in public games. It was also a place for socializing and engaging in intellectual pursuits. The name comes from the Greek term gymnos meaning naked. Athletes competed in the nude, a practice said to encourage aesthetic appreciation of the male body and a tribute to the Gods.
TEXT.German: Das Gymnasion war im antiken Griechenland eine Trainingsstätte für Athleten. Meist war es ein von Säulenhallen und Bädern gesäumter Hof. Später bezeichnete man als Gymnasion eine Bildungsstätte, wo Philosophen und Rhetoriker den Jugendlichen ihre Lehren vortrugen.
TEXT.Italian: The gymnasium in ancient Greece functioned as a training facility for competitors in public games. It was also a place for socializing and engaging in intellectual pursuits. The name comes from the Greek term gymnos meaning naked. Athletes competed in the nude, a practice said to encourage aesthetic appreciation of the male body and a tribute to the Gods.
